how: Within the visualization domain, researchers can build upon and extend established principles, frameworks, or categorization, demonstrating the fieldâ€™s evolutionary nature.
Theater, film, and literature provide insights into narrative structures and techniques that can be applied to visualization design.
Interaction design helps identify design patterns related to user interaction and user experience.
Information theory serves as another source of inspiration for the exploration phase, offering principles for quantifying and communicating information effectively.

Researchers often begin their data collection by systematically collecting relevant academic papers from scholarly database. This approach ensures a solid theoretical foundation for the design space, capturing research trends within the field.
Leveraging existing project collections is one common method. They merged these lists and removed duplicates to create a comprehensive corpus.

For unique or emerging research subjects, researchers may need to curate their own project collections. This often involves gathering examples from diverse sources such as social media, visualization repositories, design award platforms, and news agencies.
In cases where online sources are limited or quality control is a concern, researchers may opt to create their own project collections.
The comprehensive strategy explores multiple facets of visualization design, providing a holistic view that covers all or most of these key aspects.

The focused strategy concentrates on specific combinations of these aspects, allowing for a more in-depth exploration of particular properties of visualization design. It includes data-visualization-interaction focus, visualization-interaction focus and visualization-centric approach.

The extended strategy involves incorporating domain-specific aspects into either comprehensive or focused strategies, allowing researchers to address unique characteristics of particular research areas.
User studies provide quantitative, comparative data under controlled conditions, enabling statistical analysis of design spaces
Example applications and case studies demonstrate the applicability of a proposed design space to real-world problems.
Interviews capture in-depth, qualitative insights into user perceptions and requirements, often revealing unanticipated aspects of the design space.
Workshops offer hands-on, creative engagement with the design space, revealing how users interpret and apply its concepts in practice.

While textual descriptions form the foundation of this communication, researchers often employ various textual enhancements to elucidate the design space structure. These include using color coding to differentiate between design dimensions and word-scale graphics to represent specific design choices along these dimensions.
Figures provide a concise overview of design spaces, facilitating rapid comprehension of complex relationships and structures.
Interactive online explorers offer a dynamic engagement platform, allowing users to actively explore and manipulate design space elements.
Prototype systems embody the spirit of rapid visualization prototyping, moving from conceptual representation to full-scale deployment.
Method cards offer a tangible approach to design space communication, particularly effective in collaborative settings.
